content: How can I help you today?

I’ve been having a lot of trouble staying focused and present lately. My wife and I are under a lot of stress at home because of our son’s behavioral issues, and it’s putting a strain on everything—our marriage, my focus at work, my ability to enjoy time with my daughter, and even my own mental health. Honestly, I'm not even sure if this is going to help, but here I am.

That sounds really overwhelming, managing stress at home while trying to juggle so many parts of life. It seems like a lot is weighing on you right now. How has all of this been affecting you personally?

I feel drained and disconnected most of the time. It’s hard to focus on anything—work feels impossible, and I can’t remember the last time I felt genuinely happy or relaxed. I don’t even know where to start fixing things, and that just makes it worse.

It sounds like you've been carrying a lot on your shoulders, and it's leaving you feeling both mentally and emotionally exhausted. Sorting through everything probably feels pretty daunting right now. What feels most important to you in this moment—where do you think you want to begin?

Honestly, I think I just want to know how to help my son. If I can figure that out, maybe everything else will start to fall into place. I feel like he's the center of all of this stress, and I don't know what else to do.

You're really trying to do your best for your son, and it's clear how much you care about him. It sounds like the challenges with him are affecting so many parts of your life, and you’re hoping that supporting him better might help create more balance for everyone. What do you feel like you’ve tried so far that’s worked—or that hasn’t worked—when it comes to helping him?

We've tried setting up routines and being consistent with discipline, but nothing seems to stick. We've even looked into getting him evaluated, but the process feels so overwhelming and slow. My wife and I argue a lot about the best approach for him, and that only makes things more stressful for everyone.

It sounds like you’ve been making a real effort—trying routines, staying consistent, even exploring evaluations—but it’s been frustrating not seeing the progress you need. On top of that, feeling like you and your wife are not on the same page adds to the pressure. What keeps you motivated to keep trying, despite how hard it’s been?
I guess what keeps me going is that he’s my son, and I just want to help him. I want him to be okay, to grow up happy and healthy. I just feel like I’m failing him, and that’s the hardest part.

It's clear how deeply you care about him and how much you want the best for him. Feeling like you're not doing enough must weigh on you heavily, especially when you're doing everything you can think of to support him. How do you experience that sense of feeling like you're failing him? What makes you feel that way?

I think it’s because no matter what I do, nothing seems to improve. He’s still struggling, and I feel like I should be able to fix it somehow, but I can’t. It’s heartbreaking to feel so helpless as his parent.

It’s painful to feel like you’re doing everything you can and still not seeing the changes you hope for, especially when it’s someone you love so much. That helplessness must be incredibly difficult to sit with. In all of this, what gives you even a small sense of hope right now?

I guess the only thing that gives me hope is that he’s still young, and maybe there’s time to figure this out. I want to believe that there’s a way to help him, even if I don’t know what it is right now.

Holding onto that hope, even in the midst of everything, shows how much determination and love you have for your son. Believing there’s a way forward, even when it feels unclear, can be such a powerful starting point. What do you think might help you take the next step toward figuring this out—whether it’s for your son, your family, or even yourself?

Would you like some time to think together about what steps you might take next? Or is there something specific you’re already considering?

I think just having someone to help us figure out the right steps would be a start. Maybe someone who understands what my son is going through and can guide us. I don’t know what the right thing is, but I know we can’t keep going like this.

It sounds like finding someone with the experience and knowledge to guide you could make a big difference, and it’s brave to recognize when it’s time to seek that kind of support. What steps do you think you might be able to take to connect with someone who could help your son and your family?

Maybe reaching out to a professional who specializes in children’s behavioral health could be a good next step. It might also help to talk to your wife about working together on this and coming up with a plan as a team. Would that feel like a manageable place to start?

It sounds like seeking a professional's guidance could give you more clarity about your son’s needs, and partnering with your wife might strengthen the path forward for your family. Taking those first steps together could help you both feel supported. Would it help to talk about how you might approach those conversations?
